stem: The patient is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. For each assessment finding, indicate whether it is consistent with autonomic dysreflexia or requires further investigation.

itemContext.sbar: S: Patient James Miller, 45-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury sustained 5 years ago, reports a severe headache and blurred vision at 15:00. B: He's been stable until now. His usual BP is around 110/70. He's on scheduled baclofen. A: At 15:15, his BP is 210/110, HR 55, skin is flushed above the injury level, diaphoretic, and goosebumps are present. He is complaining of nasal congestion. Bladder scan showed 600 mL urine. Bowel movement was yesterday. Neuro exam shows no new deficits besides those expected from his SCI. O: I suspect autonomic dysreflexia. I have elevated the head of the bed. I'm requesting orders for immediate intervention to lower his BP and address the cause. Monitor vitals q5min. Notify provider with changes. Anticipate need for catheterization.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 15 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL, WBC: 7.5 x 10^3/uL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Baclofen 20mg PO TID (08:00, 16:00, 24:00), Docusate sodium 100mg PO daily, PRN acetaminophen for pain.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Autonomic dysreflexia is characterized by a sudden onset of excessively high blood pressure. Bradycardia is a common reflex response to the hypertension. Skin flushing above the level of injury is due to vasodilation, while diaphoresis is also a common manifestation. A full bladder is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia and requires immediate intervention.
rationale.incorrect: Normal WBC counts are not indicative of autonomic dysreflexia. While infection can be a trigger, the lab value itself does not confirm or deny the presence of autonomic dysreflexia. Further investigation is needed to determine if an infection is present.
clinicalPearls: Always assess for bladder distention and bowel impaction in patients with spinal cord injuries presenting with signs of autonomic dysreflexia.
Elevate the head of the bed immediately to lower blood pressure.

questionTrap.trap: The normal lab values might distract you into thinking the patient is stable and not experiencing a medical emergency. Focusing on the BP and symptoms described in the SBAR should guide you.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize the ABCs and recognize that vital sign changes are more indicative of the immediate problem than stable lab values. Connect the symptoms to the pathophysiology of autonomic dysreflexia.

mnemonic.title: AD
mnemonic.expansion: A: Assess BP (High!), D: Determine & remove the cause (Bladder, Bowel, Skin)

rows: Skin flushing above the level of injury
